By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
Compare 
and contrast solitary, social, and parasitic lifestyles in 
bees 
Describe 
the basic features of a solitary bee and their brood 
cells 
Compare 
and contrast diggers, renters, wood nesters and 
architects. Be able to give one example for each type 
Understand 
the difference between cooperative breeding bees 
and eusocial bees 
Describe 
the basic features of a brood parasitic bee 
Note: 
you are not required to memorize the name of the species 
featured today but you should be able to answer questions 
relative to the learning outcomes above

Basic features of a 
solitary 
bee (77.4% of bees): 
•
Each female builds and guards her own nest 
•
Each female provisions her own brood cells 
•
Each female lays her own eggs 
•
Adults are, typically, active for a very short period of time (~3 
weeks) and there is an extended period of larval or adult 
diapause 
•
Many are host
-
plant specialists

Basic features of a 
brood parasitic 
(
cleptoparasitic
) bee: 
•
Females do not build nests or collect pollen/nectar 
•
Females enter the nests of other bees and lay their eggs 
•
Eggs hatch into aggressive larvae that kill the host egg or larva 
•
Brood parasite feeds on pollen/nectar collected by host

(Stingless bees and honey bees)

Basic features of a 
social parasite
: 
•
Social parasites only attack 
social hosts 
•
Social parasites enter the nest of the host species and 
replace the host queen 
•
They can kill the host queen or simply render her inactive 
•
The social parasite uses the workforce of the host to rear her 
own reproductive offspring
